summary: Andrew Wyke (Michael Caine) is a highly successful mystery writer living in a beautiful and technologically advanced mansion in England. Milo Tindle (Jude Law) is an unsuccessful actor with decidedly less to show for his professional exploits. The lives of these two men cross paths when Andrew's wife leaves him for the younger Milo. Hoping to carry out a cleverly constructed revenge plot, Andrew invites Milo to his estate, where elaborate mind games ensue.

reviews.content: Didn't work any better for me than the original.
A good different remake that is carried well by two great actors in Jude Law and Michael Caine.
Jude Law is a tour de force, Michael Caine equally mesmerizing.  Perhaps not as engrossing as the original Sleuth but still a great watch.

Basically a “just-kidding...or am I” joke dragged out for an hour and a half. You wonder why either of the characters would stick around after the first few awkward exchanges, but then again, why did I stick around either? Just awful.

Despite Kenneth Branagh's eye for image and two devoted lead performances, Sleuth begins as merely coarsely written in a coldly lifeless setting before going further off the rails in the third act losing all intent and comprehension.
Two stars for Law as the detective, besides that... boring and meaningless. I have never seen a movie especially a mystery/thriller that had absolutely no pay off or twist. F Tier.

This movie is brilliant!  I have seen both the original and the 2007 version and they are both excellent.  It's so much fun watching  both just to see Michael Caine playing the younger character and then the older character.  This is a fascinating psychological thriller.  But, the wit and playful humor is also extremely powerful.  I have never enjoyed seeing 2 versions of a movie as much as SLEUTH.  I will say I did prefer the super sleek set of the second version over the opposite ( very cluttered  earlier version.  I felt that it really let the dialogue shine even brighter in that setting.  And Jude Law is amazing in this Kenneth Branagh version.  I thought the chemistry of Caine and Law playing off each other really cracked and sizzled.  Don't miss this film !!
Awful, soulless, uninvolving and utterly pointless remake. Caine must have been truly hard up to want to taint his original offering with this empty shell of a film!

Whereas as the original Sleuth was one of the best films ever this mangled remake of Sleuth is one of the worst films ever. Don't watch it - it may ruin your enjoyment of the original (which is what I thought I was hiring).
A very lame attempt to remake a classic. Instantly forgettable
Artsy film that plays like a theatrical play. After all, it was adapted for screen. Entertaining, puzzling, cat-n-mouse type of heavy dialogue, but don't expect a masterpiece.
Theatrical and dull with two reasonably good performances.

It began as such an interesting and intriguing film, but by the end it was becoming tiresome, and ultimately just dumb.  The acting however is truly superb.  I mean on an unusual and noteworthy scale.
I enjoyed the first 30 minutes.  The remainder is tedious at best. I gave it two stars for the acting. I am overjoyed I did not see this at the movie house.  I was overseas at the time.
Oh, fu*k you! Michael Cain was in it! Still, it's painful to see how some people just can't (big emphasis on CANNOT) backport the Theater into the Big Screen. Shame.
fuck you all! this is a great film. yes I'm just being ornery, but really? 36%?
Feels long and drawn out for 88 minutes.....that's not good.
Jude Law's League of Gentlemen audition went brilliantly.
An utter redundancy.
Not as terrible as everyone says it is. Then again, I'm not a pretentious asshole looking for some deeper meaning. I found it quite amusing.

The updated story of a wealthy writer of detective stories, and an aspiring yet out-of-work actor who is having an affair with the writer's wife. The writer's exquisitely modernized Georgian manor becomes the backdrop for a cat and mouse game that pits one creative mind against another.

I saw the original 1972 film when it had it's first theatrical release and loved it. I was intrigued by this remake and it was very interesting, as any film would be with a Pinter screenplay, Branagh's direction, and Michael Caine and Jude Law for the protagonists. Although this pic was good, the original was slightly better with more twists and turns. One factor to that was the shortened length, of  course. The homosexual element in the original was implied, but not clearly stated as here, but then it was 1972, after all. Even though not quite as good, in the world of remakes, where new is usually horribly inferior, this is a stellar one.
Completely wasting third act, intrigue became unfounded absurd.

Cat & Mouse Character Drama Is At Times Bizzare, Twists & Turns, But Works It Way Through To An Alright End. The Face-Off Between The Two (Similar Acting Styles) Old/New Caine/Law Is A Brilliant Combination Though. I'm Not Surprised Jude Sought Michael Out For This Little Project Of His.
Very fun -- I have not seen the original, witty, unpredictable, and Caine and Law are clearly having a great time.
This film was ok - 3 stars.

I personally found Sluth difficult to watch. And that is strange because it has two very fine actors playing the major rolls, never the less this film left me feeling very hollow once I had finally forced myself to the end. Perhaps it was the environment, I find "modern" house architecture total nonsense so watching an entire film set in this kind of environment very difficult.
Also I have very fond memories of the 1975 version that was set in a castle I believe and had far more atmosphere than this film. The film was also very predictable hardly straying from the original in story so there were no real surprises when it all came down to it. Who ever decided to set this in a modern "artsy" house should be boxed behind the ears, it ruined the entire film.   1 Star  12-19-13

A fine reimagining of the excellent play that was so well filmed in 1972. The script is fine and the performances by the two man cast are superb. Still, very good as this version is, I prefer the earlier version for both screenplay and performances.
Very well made movie got kinda awkward in the gay part at the end!! Not a homophobe!!
Worst than the Original Version -_-
let down - goes on forever and really doesn't have an ending per say. Felt kind of hichcock-ish.
Possibly the worst movie i've ever seen.  Doesn't even deserve the half star i'm giving.  2 actors...1 house...and 100% crap.   *yawns*
Not as good as the original, but if you never saw that, it's got some twists worth seeing.  Doubt this film will hit Branagh's resume.
Low expectations means this film doesn't seems so bad
I know that I've seen it, and I think I thought it was ... okay.
Great acting, cool location, god awful script and directing. Go watch the 1972 version, it is very good.

Still a fantastic plot, but terribly executed. An embarrassment to the original film, especially for Michael Caine. Cheesy cinematography full of gimmicky "artsy" shots and distracting lighting. Screenplay is riddled with pointless swearing and is over-acted by Jude Law.
This movie gets a lot of hate but it is just fantastic, Normally I hate Jude Law but in this film he was brilliant! This is a must see for anyone with decent taste in movies.

The most amazing thing about this movie is its witty conversations. Both Sir Caine and Jude Law give such outstanding performances. It's one of the very rare movie that only have two characters and it still rocks.
Smart, funny and thoroughly enjoyable. Who knew that Jude Law can act?
While it boasts fantastic acting and brilliant cinematography, Sleuth seems to drag along, more so after 70 minutes has gone by.

An entertaining and well-acted update on the classic Anthony Shaffer play and film, with Branagh's inventive direction adding more dimensions (including the theme of constant surveillance) to the story. However, the story suffers from a bizarre tonal shift courtesy of Mr. Pinter two-thirds of the way through and never fully recovers, leading to an anti-climax, whereas the original earned its shocking ending in 1970/72.

I like the film atmosphere and also the plot.
I love these dialogues: 

"Andrew Wyke: A great branch broke off a big tree and - flew through the air, through the skylight - as you can see. Act of God.
Detective Inspector Black: Had it in for you, did he?
Andrew Wyke: Who?
Detective Inspector Black: God.
Andrew Wyke: Oh, yes, he's always been a vicious bastard.
Andrew Wyke: You know what God's trouble is?
Detective Inspector Black: What?
Andrew Wyke: He has no father. He has no family roots. He's rootless. Nowhere to hang his hat, poor bugger. I pity him. "
exciting with fine performances.

The original 'Sleuth' was a brilliant (actually amazing) film. The 2007 film is a vulgar, ugly, attempt at being stylish led by two usually competent artists: Pinter (who over-writes word after word) and Branagh (whose camera movements are sickening). The character of Andrew Wyke looks like a wining, spoiled, overly-rich brat and despite two good performances this obsolete remake isn't worth anyone's time.

Luckily for me, I didn't watch the original 1972 version of Sleuth, so I didn't know what to expect before begin to watch it, or did I have any previous basis of comparison. That's a good thing, as this stylish film (pleasure for arquitects and designers) keep me curious about what's happen next. Now, this may seem short for a film like this, but for me was a satisfying feature, that'll leave you highly entertained once the credits start to roll.

speaking of the movie that relies heavily on two actors (really)... this could be one of them... I admire both Jude Law and Michael Caine for pulling up a movie that has both of their faces all through out the film... both really did well...kudos also to the director for coming out with all of the possible angles needed to make a movie as it is... only problem I had is that the film is a bit confusing or maybe I haven't fully grasped the message of the film yet.. I heard that the original is good... hoping to watch it soon...

Despite the brilliant actors in it, Jude Law and Michael Caine, both my big favorites, this is just.... DULL and BOORING. Kenneth Branagh makes excellent films and tv-shows as well as utter s..... A funny detail: Michael Cain played the role of Jude Law in the original 1972 version. Wanted to see it, on principle, but as I read, it is almost twice the length and none the more exiting, I think I pass.....
I'd like it, but the almost homo scene makes me sick.
I loved it even though most people seemed to have had a problem with it. The acting is phenomenal and the intensity of the script stays with you even after the movie is over.

I could, if I liked, and were inclined to do so, sum this up in one word. Annoying.

Why am I annoyed by it? Firstly, Kenneth Branagh's almost studenty and first-time-director-type weirdo camera angles and security cam cut-aways are annoying - they scream 'lack of confidence', which a seasoned filmmaker such as he has no need for. Secondly, the lack of chemistry between Caine and Law is annoyingly baffling - usually, both actors could read out the phonebook and have me riveted, but for some reason there's just no zing here. Third and lastly, the writing is appalling, and comes off like Pinter writing a deliberately Pinter-esque script and sending himself up. Considering the stuff that Harold Pinter was capable of producing, this noticeable blip is annoying.

a  deadly  game  of cat  and  mouse  Micheal Caine  and Jude Law's  characters    at  first  glance  are  like two  mirror  images  of  each  other   both  playing  a game   and  they  play  it  well  but  to  see  Micheal  character  go  from  sweet  to   cold, deceptive,psychotic, and  villainous  which  i think  is  quite  brilliant  where  as  Jude  Law's  character  went  from  timid,  cowardly, completely  unraveling  at  the  seams  to  being  quite  the  villain  himself better  than  Micheal's  character   but  sadly  the game  ended
game  match  and set  overall  i quite  enjoyed   mystery  and  suspense  thriller  definitely  kept  me  entertained  though  i couldn't  help  second  guessing  what or  what  was  going  to happen  next  it's  quite  true  what  you  think is  the ending  isn't  always  the  end  result   Kudos  to  the  cast  and  their  performances  and  to  the director
Fool Milo at first. Fool Milo at the end.
Exellent cinematography, good acting and good story.
Jude Law needs a new job.
So apparently Jude Law can act and Michael Caine has slightly more range than I had previously given him credit for.  It does feel like a play though.
Two great actors playing the ultimate mind games.  Absolutely amazing!  Definitely worth watching.
I will never get that 90 minutes back. That would have even been a terrible movie in the 80's.
Not as much thrilling as the original one , but Michael Caine was awesome
Director Kenneth Branagh clearly is having fun navigating Tim Harvey's slick set design, but eventually the characters' deadly competitiveness becomes tedious.
Incredibly entertaining with humor, wit and great actors

The whole movie is based on two character's alone. I've seen another movie that also based the storyline on two characters. Though that movie was boring, however this movie kept my interest.  I'm not a Law fan but many women love him. I loved some of the screen capture shots in this film, very interesting.
Clever and witty dialogue between Caine & Law quickly turns stale in the final hour.
Amazingly well-played and very interesting. (and Jude Law is super-hot as always! ;) )

Phenomenal piece of cinema. Two greats opposing each other beautifully in this extremely dark and intertwining love story of sorts. Not a conventional tale of love, that is to say, rather a tale of the tolls love can take on the psyche, the costs it can extract, and the pains it can force one to endure, or, enact on others. 
While the original is indeed a superior movie- if be lying to myself if I didn't say that the remake holds it's own very well, and is only lower rated due to the shape of the shadow it's cast under.

Caine and Law rustle up a spicy chemistry which sustains a sizzle for an hour or so. But the second half panders to Pinter's self-indulgence, unravelling Branagh's high-tensile head-fuck as a hollow skirmish.

Strange, strange movie. I'd never thought I'd say this, but Jude Law absolutely blew me away. Normally I am resigned to thinking, "Eh, he was pretty good" after watching his films, but here his character ranged from polite to jittery to downright maniacal. And of course, I could watch Michael Caine read the phone book for two hours and be perfectly content. I may need to watch this again in order to properly assess my feelings but yeah, it's a lot of fun.
I liked the acting a lot, and that alone captivated me.
Such an interesting movie it grabs your attention and never let go till the very end, even then, you wonder what is to become of the two men? (well, maybe one)
It's a different movie kind of draggy. Kind of funny that Michael Caine was Jude Law's character in the 1972 version.

2 3/4 - Quite the little cat and mouse game. Jude Law and Michael Caine play 2 men, in love with the same woman, sucked into a game of wits and trickery in order to win her. The first game was quite entertaining since I had no idea what I was getting myself into. The second was much more since it had only elevated the suspense. By the third game, I was almost confused and then I was bored. Over-all it was just bizarre and I didn't like it. I rated it higher than I should've because the performances were quite brilliant. Caine could chill you to the bone and Law is just plain mad really, exceptionally mad.
Intelligent, witty movie. But like many films of the genre, chose the easy way to end the show. Good actors though.
Blondes do have more fun. But they also experience more jealousy, anger, and murder as well.
This movie was based on a play and you could tell.I bet watching the play is better then the movie.

A poor remake of a charming witty thriller. Even good performances doesn't save the show as after an interesting opening, it becomes tedious and darker where bit by bit you couldn't careless with either of them.
High notes -
Ac - Michael Caine
Primarily interesting, but overall weird and not worth the time it demands.

Slow moving and at times confusing. I didn't enjoy Kenneth Branagh's camera angles. They gave me a headache. What I did enjoy was the very subtle changes in the characters.  Brilliant acting by the only two characters is worth sitting through it.  Sad that the updated version had to include totally unnecessary naughty words.  One of the characters is a world renowned writer and the other is an actor. Having these two go for the eff word and the C word just didn't go with who they were as people.  Over all a decent change of pace from the usual Saturday night explosion fest.
Not really a remake but a reimagining of the 1972 film of the same name..Caine and Law do a fine job with cutting edge dialog.
Despite not being a solid as it 1972 original, Caine and Law's slow building performances still give its remake a twisted thrill
Why bother remaking this Michael? Why? Third act is definitely wayward.
I bought this DVD assuming it was the original, boy did I regret this. The whole movie looks like a stage play rehearsal. It is under produced and actors lacked conviction.

love the fascinating verbal duel that goes on in the movie..it wasn't critically or commercially (??) well received but i just love the rapid,razor sharp dialogue exchanged by the two actors-michael caine(one of my fave actors)who is wickedly terrific and jude law who does a good job too...the only (rather big) letdown is the third act which really disappointed me...but the first couple of acts are just "two" good....
Jude Law and Michael Caine are good enough to handle the whole movie by themselves.

Before anything, I have to be frank about two facts. One: I have not seen the original 1972 Sleuth. Two: I love Jude Law and I think he is one of the most brilliant actors of our time.
The movie is extremely witty, story-wise, script-wise and even performance-wise. The story of the film is an adaptation of a 1970 play by Anthony Shaffer. That is why throughout the movie, I kept imagining Law and Caine as if they were on stage in this man-to-man show. However, Kenneth Branagh, whom I consider as a phenomenal actor (not sure about him being a director), did a good job, not entirely perfect I have to say, in bringing this play to the silver screen.
As I said, the script is extremely witty, thanks to Harold Pinter of course, beautifully crystallizing the mind games between the two characters. Nevertheless, I found some scenes quite bizarre and over-dramatized, but they did not stop me from enjoying the movie though, and enjoying the outstanding chemistry between Michael Caine and Jude Law. Not only are they brilliant actors, but also they have managed to establish this special bond from scene one.
You might not love the movie as I did, but it is certainly one you don't want to miss.
I very much enjoyed this to the fullest. Very witty and brilliant acting.

Atrocious directional choices and horribly overblown performances, Branagh spends most of his time sliding his camera around the slick, shiny sets and in the process he succesfully kills a wonderful play and all memory of the charming original film.

It's nice to see Jude Law and Michael Caine working side by side and their performances are stella, but it's a shame that the material is lacking and ultimately unworthy of their ability. As a play I can see it working, as a film, it does not. Then again the ending still sucks so if I did see it as a play I'd still be disappointed.
"Were you breastfed?" "Yeah, like a baby"
A massively underrated film, Kenneth Branagh's remake of Sleuth is extremely well written, acted, and directed.
I enjoyed the cat and mouse game between Caine and Law. They had great chemistry on screen.
It was a long time ago I rated this movie..I dunno what happened. Anyways, this was an amazing piece of work and I reccommend it to anyone that likes great character pieces/stage plays.

A very cool movie! But Jude Law was a little too psycho for me, haha. And I like the fact that there was like, no cast other than Jude Law and Michael Caine. The plot was twisty and very clever. Although, predictable. Well, maybe it was supposed to be predictable to the audience, but not to the characters in the movie. I don't know.
Incredibly smart and well done movie. Great dialogue and acting. Loved it.
I adore this movie with all of my heart and soul.
Weird but well-written and clever.
I like Jude Law's acting. Really strong!
Not Branagh's best movie, but quite interesting, and quite witty anyway. Michael Caine and Jude Law are amazing.
It starts not bad, as the original one, but the last part becomes too twisted.

I couldn't even continue watching this crap. It inserts a homosexual element that doesn't even make sense in some attempt to update it, but it really makes little sense and never engages the audience. Just dull, sparse and sad.
Caine+Branagh+Law+Pinter
Well, I didn't see that coming. (Apart from that thing in the middle, that was a bit embarrassing.)
